Posts.Content: I wouldn't put too much stock in the New York Times article. It is possible that outcomes are being over-promised, which would explain the disappointment. However, what really matters is what is your outcome relative to the alternatives. You can never know, but if you listen to the person making the 4th comment on the NYT article, he says, "When in doubt, do nothing." This, in my opinion, is not a good strategy for dealing with PC. In May of this year, my younger brother died of PC. I was diagnosed with PC on August 11. On August 26 I had my prostate removed by RP by someone who has done hundreds of these surgeries. I was very comfortable with his advice and that of my primary urologist. If you are in good health and have T2 PC, surgery appears to give the best outcome. I will also say that I do not care if I ever have another erection and that I would rather live with some incontinence that allow cancer to continue to grow in my body after what I saw my brother go through. Dying of PC is much worse than not having sex or wearing a diaper.
Posts.Title: Side effects after Da Vinci Robotic Surgery!

Posts.Content: I am 61 and my cancer was also discovered by DRE. My PSA was 2.9. My biopsy put me on Gleason 3+3, stage T2a. I had a RRP on Tuesday and left the hospital on Wednesday. I have six incisions on the same horizontal plane as my belly button. The biggest hassle so far is the catheter, but like anything, you learn ways to handle it. I'm very happy with my outcome so far. In a few days the catheter will come out, I'll get my pathology report, and, with luck, this thing will be over. Best of luck to you.

Posts.Title: Side effects after Da Vinci Robotic Surgery!

Posts.Content: Ok, a lot of water has passed (under the bridge), and I'm still about the same place, maybe a little worse. There are certain times where a clamp would be helpful like when I'm playing tennis or golf or working in the yard. Of course, I like to have the occasional beer while I'm doing these things, and that really makes it worse. So, I'd like recommendations from anyone who has experience.
Posts.Title: Who Uses Penile Clamps?

Posts.Content: I had my surgery over five years ago, so not much chance things are going to change for the better. I've looked at the clamps on line, and they are just some foam which slightly compresses the penis to restrict flow, and I would not wear it for more than a couple hours. One thing that I have been doing in the meantime, and which is most helpful, is to wear the most tight fitting underwear I can get into (bikini style) along with a pad.
Posts.Title: Who Uses Penile Clamps?

Posts.Content: You obviously don't know what you're talking about, and no I'm not seeing a doctor about my underwear. Good grief!
Posts.Title: Who Uses Penile Clamps?

Posts.Content: I had my surgery over five years ago, so not much chance things are going to change for the better. I've looked at the clamps on line, and they are just some foam which slightly compresses the penis to restrict flow, and I would not wear it for more than a couple hours. One thing that I have been doing in the meantime, and which is most helpful, is to wear the most tight fitting underwear I can get into (bikini style) along with a pad.
Posts.Title: Who Uses Penile Clamps?

Posts.Content: I'm about 7 weeks since surgery and my urinary incontinence is not changing much. I use 2 to 3 pads per day. The whole thing is entirely manageable and I do think it will eventually improve. However, there is one area where leaking is more of a problem, and that is when I am playing tennis or engaged in other physical activity. I think a clamp, which I see advertised on the internet, might be useful in these circumstances. Anyone have experience with these devices?

Posts.Title: Who Uses Penile Clamps?

Posts.Content: I've been living with mild incontinence ever since my prostatectomy in 2008. I'm getting tired of it, and it seems to be getting a little worse, so I am interested in this device/operation. Anyone know anything about it? http://www.webmd.com/urinary-inconti...tinence-in-men
Posts.Title: Artificial sphincter for incontinence

Posts.Content: For a long time I used these: https://www.depend.com/en-us/incontinence-products/men/guards-for-men I use three or four per day. They worked well enough, but I had severe itching of anus. Happenstance caused we to try these: https://www.walmart.com/ip/Assurance-Guards-for-Men-Maximum-One-Size-Fits-All-52-Ct/843897280 Same or better containment, but itching is gone! The Assurance pads are slightly shorter, so I'm not sure if it's that or some allergic condition.
Posts.Title: Incontinence pad experience

Posts.Content: BTW, I had Da Vinci prostatectomy in 2008. All ok but for the incontinence.
Posts.Title: Incontinence pad experience
